Dear BRANDON HANNAH:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 07/28/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at.
Sincerely,
Christopher M Barr, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each employee and shall
include documentation of all of the following information prior to employment
or at the time specified in this rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic violations from
either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police records or
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian

province, or other country where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous five years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or
other country law enforcement agency where the
person usually resides or has resided in the previous
five years.
One staff record out of 27 reviewed contained a ICHAT completed five days after the date
of hire. The staff was hired on 12/01/2022, whereas the ICHAT was completed on
12/05/2022.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each employee and shall
include documentation of all of the following information prior to employment
or at the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human services,
the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or equivalent
agency in the country where the person usually resides, that the
person has not been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse
or child neglect. The documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment and every 12 months
thereafter.
One staff record out of 27 reviewed contained a central registry check completed beyond
30 days prior to the start of employment. The staff was hired on 05/22/2023, whereas the
central registry check was completed on 10/31/2022, 174 days beyond 30-days. It is
noted that the staff person was rehired by the facility.
R 400.4167 Case record maintenance.
(4) Records shall be maintained in a uniform and organized manner, shall be
protected against destruction and damage, and shall be stored in a
manner that safeguards confidentiality.
Four out of eight resident discharge summaries were not uploaded into the facility’s
electronic case record system, Salesforce.
R 400.4527 Sprinkler systems.
(2) All required sprinkler systems shall be inspected and tested and all other

maintenance performed as specified in the 2014 national fire protection
association standard No. 25 entitled “Standards for the Inspection, Testing,
and Maintenance of Water-Based Fire Protection Systems” at least once a
year by a sprinkler contractor. The licensee shall maintain documentation
of the last inspection and test.
The 07/27/2023 fire inspection verbal findings note the fire department connection shall
not be obstructed or otherwise obscured from plain site. Remove any shrubbery plants or
weeds obstructing its view from the street side.
R 400.4560 Cooking appliances.
(3) In a newly constructed, remodeled, or converted large and secure facility,
where metal hoods or canopies are provided over commercial kitchen
cooking appliances, they shall be designed and equipped incompliance with
the national fire protection association standard No. 96, entitled “Standard
for Ventilation Control and Fire Protection of Commercial Cooking
Operations.” 2014, and shall comply with all of the following requirements:
(d) Fire extinguishment equipment for the hood and exhaust duct of
a cooking appliance in a kitchen shall be in compliance with the
national fire protection association standard 96, entitled “Standard
for Ventilation Control and Fire Protection of Commercial Cooking
Operations.”
The 07/27/2023 fire inspection verbal findings note hood extinguishing system with
constant shall be serviced bi-annually in accordance with NFPA 96.
R 400.4506 Fire drills.
(1) There shall be quarterly emergency fire drills for each staff shift. Two of
the drills shall include evacuations, unless approved by the department,
in writing, as clinically indicated. Where a facility has a 24-hour staff shift,
the emergency drills shall be conducted at times of the day and niht.
Written records shall be maintained for each drill indicating the date and
time of the drill and, where evacuation was part of the drill, the
approximate evacuation time.
The 07/27/2023 fire inspection verbal findings note improper drills need to on each shift.
Corrective articulated and is being implemented. Must be written.
R 400.4543 Doors.
(4) Interior doors to any enclosure which is required to have not less than a

1-hour fire resistance rating shall be B-labeled fire doors in labeled frames
and shall be equipped with positive-latching hardware and self-closing
devices.
The 07/27/2023 fire inspection verbal findings notes replace all missing door knobs that
are not positive latching due to either being removed or damaged.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
128 (1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program for new employees.
Job shadowing shall not be the only form of orientation.
The facility's Paycor system documents orientation training as occurring. It
does not indicate the specific types of trainings being completed and review of
the physical file was required to determine compliance. It is recommended that
all orientation training be listed, total number of hours and dates of completion
for each training noted.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Involved staff terminated, received disciplinary measures, retrained in
restraint techniques and incident reporting.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: CAP's
appear to have been appropriately handled to include ther terminations of involved
staff, staff receiving diciplinary measures, retraining in restraint techniques and
incident reporting.

Financial Overview
The facility's 2021 financial audit through 09/2021 indicates operational
compliance.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The facility does not serve juvenile justice youth.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Facility completed its annual chief administrator assessment for the period of
08/2022 through 07/2023.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff report being adequately supported by management and notes the changing
and increasingly challenging behaviors of youth placed.
Youth report receiving needed services, adequate meals, and appropriate
recreation time.
Description of Agency Walk Through
Facility is adequately cleaned and organized for programming implementation.
Tiled floors throughout the aged facility make for loud acoustics.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
